rsbNotes.title: Ps 51
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 51 Ps. 51 is a uniquely powerful statement of the depths of sin and repentance. It is the most striking of the “prayers of penitence” (introduction to Ps. 6), a type of lament.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:1
rsbNotes.text:
51:1 according to your steadfast love. David had been guilty of a great sin in the matter of Uriah, husband of Bathsheba (2 Sam. 11). David pleads for God’s mercy, in keeping with His promised love for His people.

mercy. God’s forgiveness of sinners is the result of His mercy. Sinners deserve death, but He gives life.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:2
rsbNotes.text: 51:2 Wash. The word means specifically to “wash clothes.” The psalmist’s iniquity is like filthy clothes that need to be laundered.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:4
rsbNotes.text:
51:4 you only. David committed adultery with Bathsheba and sent her husband to his death. How can he say he sinned against God only? Rebellion against God was the root of his sin, and his crime injured people who belonged to God and transgressed a social order created by God.

justified . . . blameless. David recognized that God’s anger against him was just. This verse is cited by Paul in Rom. 3:4.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:5
rsbNotes.text: 51:5 brought forth in iniquity. The Bible clearly teaches that children are sinners. They are not born innocent and only later become sinners. Children, too, need God’s salvation. See theological note “Original Sin and Total Depravity.”

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:6
rsbNotes.text: 51:6 the inward being . . . the secret heart. That is, truth and wisdom at the center of one’s being.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:7
rsbNotes.text:
51:7 with hyssop. The allusion is to Lev. 14:6, 7, where the cleansing of a leper is described.

wash me. This may be an allusion to Num. 19:19, where instructions are given for ritual washing after contact with a dead person. On the need for washing the heart, see “Legalism” at Matt. 23:4.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:10
rsbNotes.text: 51:10 Create. The verb is the same used at Gen. 1:1 for the creation of the world. The psalmist knows that the redirection of his desires and thoughts can only come about through the intervention of God. See “Repentance” at Acts 26:20.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:11
rsbNotes.text: 51:11 Holy Spirit. The Old Testament does not make a full disclosure of the personhood of the Holy Spirit. David understands that his spiritual well-being depends on God’s presence with him. He fears that the Spirit may be taken away, because the Spirit is holy and David is sinful. See “The Holy Spirit” at John 14:26.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:12
rsbNotes.text: 51:12 joy of your salvation. David had suffered from a spiritual dullness that led to moral bankruptcy. To prevent such disaster in the future, he prays for joy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:13
rsbNotes.text: 51:13 I will teach transgressors your ways. If forgiven, the psalmist promises to use his life to help others find forgiveness.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:14
rsbNotes.text: 51:14 sing aloud of your righteousness. David has previously spoken of God’s justice in condemning sin (v. 4). Now, the same justice overcomes sin and condemnation through grace, as explained in Rom. 3:21–26 and epitomized in 1 John 1:9.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:16
rsbNotes.text: 51:16 you will not be pleased with a burnt offering. The Bible values heartfelt obedience above outward religious conformity (40:6–8; Mic. 6:6–8). As v. 19 shows, this did not condemn sacrifices as such.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 51:18–19
rsbNotes.text: 51:18, 19 The restoration of the king leads to blessing for the people.
